comment_body: retest vsimage please

> @tahmed-dev
> May I ask what usage scenarios need to change the source port to a non-standard port?
> Does this special format packet exist in a general environment?

@irene-pan1202 those special format packet may not exit for compliant DHCP clients. We seen some interaction with other feature that would alter the src MAC. The test case is to ensure that those packet still go through.

@tahmed-dev 
What feature do you mean? Will it change src MAC? or src port? 
Does this special format packet only appear in Azure networks?
Thanks for your reply.

> @tahmed-dev
> What feature do you mean? Will it change src MAC? or src port?
> Does this special format packet only appear in Azure networks?
> Thanks for your reply.

snat Feature for src Port. Those test cases do not change src MAC though.

> @tahmed-dev
> Do you mean SNAT Source Network Address Translation?
> Why does SNAT change the dhcp packet? Not only for ip packet?

@irene-pan1202 Yes, it is source NAT. Can you please elaborate on the second question?
Do we need to update run_tests.sh?
@bingwang-ms Yes, need another PR to update run_tests.sh.

Maybe it is more concise to use argument like `"--power_off_delay=8,9,10"` to specify multiple delay values.

> Maybe it is more concise to use argument like `"--power_off_delay=8,9,10"` to specify multiple delay values.

Do you mean set the option as an string and split it by ","?

> > Maybe it is more concise to use argument like `"--power_off_delay=8,9,10"` to specify multiple delay values.
> 
> Do you mean set the option as an string and split it by ","?

Yes, it looks tedious to repeat this argument multiple times.

> > > Maybe it is more concise to use argument like `"--power_off_delay=8,9,10"` to specify multiple delay values.
> > 
> > 
> > Do you mean set the option as an string and split it by ","?
> 
> Yes, it looks tedious to repeat this argument multiple times.

Fixed.

@vsenchyshyn  we want to run DHCP for T1 and T0 . why we skip DHCP running ?

> @vsenchyshyn we want to run DHCP for T1 and T0 . why we skip DHCP running ?

https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/blob/master/dockers/docker-orchagent/copp.json.j2#L38 
Since there is no dhcp trap group for non ToR router DHCP packets won't be trapped to CPU. Is there any sense to run it in such case? For ToR the test will be run.

> > @vsenchyshyn we want to run DHCP for T1 and T0 . why we skip DHCP running ?
> 
> https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/blob/master/dockers/docker-orchagent/copp.json.j2#L38
> Since there is no dhcp trap group for non ToR router DHCP packets won't be trapped to CPU. Is there any sense to run it in such case? For ToR the test will be run.

Yes my last PR change was specific for that. We want to verify no packet should come to CPU for DHCP on T1

> > > @vsenchyshyn we want to run DHCP for T1 and T0 . why we skip DHCP running ?
> > 
> > 
> > https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/blob/master/dockers/docker-orchagent/copp.json.j2#L38
> > Since there is no dhcp trap group for non ToR router DHCP packets won't be trapped to CPU. Is there any sense to run it in such case? For ToR the test will be run.
> 
> Yes my last PR change was specific for that. We want to verify no packet should come to CPU for DHCP on T1

Ok, will modify it

This pull request **introduces 1 alert** when merging b3dc6cd94b5d96b33a5eef953dff688b5ba48f83 into 28d01c43db59d7d58065757467f5d9ac9eedffd7 - [view on LGTM.com](https://lgtm.com/projects/g/Azure/sonic-mgmt/rev/pr-7c9d410e8361c77c0940817b4a210be6f781497b)

**new alerts:**

* 1 for Wrong number of arguments in a call
@abdosi Could you please take a look once more?
can you please briefly explain exact issue you were hitting and on what topology ?

> can you please briefly explain exact issue you were hitting and on what topology ?
I'm hitting two issues on ptf32 topology:

1. Policer tests issue with IP2ME, SNMP, SSH tests as now the copp config is regenerated each time swss is restarted. So, the config changes copp test makes in  swss:/etc/swss/config.d/00-copp.config.json are overwritten by the config generated from template when swss container starts after config reload initiated by the test case. To fix this I comment out copp config generation in /usr/bin/start.sh inside limit_policer() and uncomment it back in restore_policer()

2. DHCP no policer test fails as on ptf32 the DUT type is LeafRouter as well. So, DHCP packets are not trapped to CPU. That's why I check not for topology type but for the DUT type for DHCP test running.
..

> > can you please briefly explain exact issue you were hitting and on what topology ?
> > I'm hitting two issues on ptf32 topology:
> 
> 1. Policer tests issue with IP2ME, SNMP, SSH tests as now the copp config is regenerated each time swss is restarted. So, the config changes copp test makes in  swss:/etc/swss/config.d/00-copp.config.json are overwritten by the config generated from template when swss container starts after config reload initiated by the test case. To fix this I comment out copp config generation in /usr/bin/start.sh inside limit_policer() and uncomment it back in restore_policer()
> 2. DHCP no policer test fails as on ptf32 the DUT type is LeafRouter as well. So, DHCP packets are not trapped to CPU. That's why I check not for topology type but for the DUT type for DHCP test running.
>    ..

@abdosi we are also noticing 1) in the lab w/ the latest 201911 changes.

I think it is better to have a sonic-buildimage ticket to track this error log when we add it to the ignore list. Otherwise, we may lose tracking of this problem.

> I think it is better to have a sonic-buildimage ticket to track this error log when we add it to the ignore list. Otherwise, we may lose tracking of this problem.

You mean raising an issue in `sonic-buildimage`, right?

> > I think it is better to have a sonic-buildimage ticket to track this error log when we add it to the ignore list. Otherwise, we may lose tracking of this problem.
> 
> You mean raising an issue in `sonic-buildimage`, right?

Yes.

The error messages in syslog that are being ignored don't seem to be related to the steps in this test. Should these be moved into the common ignored messages in common/plugins/loganalyzer/loganalyzer_common_ignore.txt

> We have some ansible libraries like ansible/library/show_interface.py for similar purposes. Can you make this code shared so that these library would also benefit from it?

This method is not directly visible to the customized ansible modules under ansible/library. But sure, I'll investigate how to make the modules benefit from this change.
@yvolynets-mlnx please also take a look, thank you!

@daall 
> Some test cases got moved out of the test_drop_counters file in a recent PR and I couldn't tell a clear reason why from the PR, so I moved them back.

The reason is explained in the original PR. 
All the test cases that were moved to drop_packets.py file are test cases the can be used for several test files and not only to drop_counters.py test. 
An additional test_*.py file, will implement the do_test() fixture as well, and the proper function will be executed according to the callee test file.
you can see the motivation and an example in this PR - 
https://github.com/noaOrMlnx/SONiC/blob/9d5438a55f1a877b2fbd1da612566ff732ed5ee2/docs/what-just-happened/what-just-happened_test_plan.md

We need those tests to be in the common file, so it would be great to revert it back to how it was.

> @daall
> 
> > Some test cases got moved out of the test_drop_counters file in a recent PR and I couldn't tell a clear reason why from the PR, so I moved them back.
> 
> The reason is explained in the original PR.
> All the test cases that were moved to drop_packets.py file are test cases the can be used for several test files and not only to drop_counters.py test.
> An additional test_*.py file, will implement the do_test() fixture as well, and the proper function will be executed according to the callee test file.
> you can see the motivation and an example in this PR -
> https://github.com/noaOrMlnx/SONiC/blob/9d5438a55f1a877b2fbd1da612566ff732ed5ee2/docs/what-just-happened/what-just-happened_test_plan.md
> 
> We need those tests to be in the common file, so it would be great to revert it back to how it was.

Ah okay, so that is what "add common drops to drop_counters.py" meant. :) I'll put it back, thanks!

@daall would you be able to review, merge? This replaces the sleep timeout with a polled wait for bgp convergence. I checked with bgp experts inside of Broadcom and I was told that 30 seconds may not be enough time, more like 120 (they suggested we try 180 but sticking with the 120 here).

#2032 opened to track the overall `ptfadapter` issue.

I ran into similar ptf issues when debugging vxlan-decap. Scapy used by ptf failed to capture some packets sometimes. I'm not sure about the root cause for now. I'll update in #2032 when it happened again. 
Just a small suggestion, have you tried to increase the qlen (like from 1000 to 2000 or 10000?) besides this update?

> I ran into similar ptf issues when debugging vxlan-decap. Scapy used by ptf failed to capture some packets sometimes. I'm not sure about the root cause for now. I'll update in #2032 when it happened again.
> Just a small suggestion, have you tried to increase the qlen (like from 1000 to 2000 or 10000?) besides this update?

Sounds good!

I haven't tried adjusting the qlen yet. I don't know that it makes sense to in this scenario since we're only sending 1 packet per test case, so 1000 should be plenty. Maybe I am misunderstanding something about how the ptf works/receives traffic?

> > I ran into similar ptf issues when debugging vxlan-decap. Scapy used by ptf failed to capture some packets sometimes. I'm not sure about the root cause for now. I'll update in #2032 when it happened again.
> > Just a small suggestion, have you tried to increase the qlen (like from 1000 to 2000 or 10000?) besides this update?
> 
> Sounds good!
> 
> I haven't tried adjusting the qlen yet. I don't know that it makes sense to in this scenario since we're only sending 1 packet per test case, so 1000 should be plenty. Maybe I am misunderstanding something about how the ptf works/receives traffic?

The 1000 qlen seems enough if that is the case. Hoping clean dataplane would address this issue. Let's keep watching.

We are also looking to add support to be able to run sonic-mgmt tests against multiple duts. With this approach, do you have ideas on how would other fixtures like ptfhost, fanouthosts, creds, collect_techsupport, sanity_check etc. handle multiple duts.

> Our approach has been to add --test_multi_duts as a pytest parser option.
> 
> ```
>    parser.addoption("--test_multi_duts", action="store_true", default=False,
>                      help="Whether to run test against all the DUTs in the dut list or not")
> ```
If the testbed defines multiple `DUT`s, like the following:
```
spytest,spytest,fullmesh,docker-ptf-brcm,ptf-unknown,<ip>,,server_host,,[lab-a7060-spy-0;lab-a7060-spy-1;lab-a7060-spy-2],hellospytest
```
Is there a need to explicitly pass `--test_multi_duts`?
> 
> Then we add a fixture test_multil_duts that returns True if the '--tests_multi_duts' option is specified
> 
> ```
> @pytest.fixture(scope="session")
> def test_multi_duts(request):
>     return request.config.option.test_multi_duts
> ```
> 
> We then modify each fixture that was dependent on just duthost, to be now dependent on test_multi_duts, duthost, and duthosts. If test_multi_duts is True, then we loop through all the DUTs, else we do the action for duthost. Example:
> 
> ```
> @pytest.fixture(scope="module", autouse=True)
> def reset_critical_services_list(test_multi_duts, duthost, duthosts):
>     """
>     Resets the critical services list between test modules to ensure that it is
>     left in a known state after tests finish running.
>     """
>     if test_multi_duts:
>         [reset_critical_services_list for a_dut in duthosts]
>     else:
>         duthost.reset_critical_services_tracking_list()
> ```
> 
> Similarly, we could modify the conn_graph fixture as follows:
> 
> ```
> @pytest.fixture(scope="module")
> def conn_graph_facts(test_multi_duts, duthost, duthosts, localhost):
>     if test_multi_duts:
>         return get_graph_facts(duthosts, localhost, [dh.hostname for dh in duthosts])
>     else:
>         return get_graph_facts(duthost, localhost, duthost.hostname)
>     
> ```
If I'm getting this right, for all related fixtures, there will be a conditional check to decide whether it is a single `DUT` or multiple, right?

The test_multi_duts is added as an option to be backward compatible with existing functionality - where I can test against a single dut using 'dut_index'.

The goal is to make the OC tests work against multiple duts. The conditional check allow us to transition smoothly fixture by fixture, and then test by test.

I think your patch is ok. I have to prototype more with our approach to make sure it works.  I was just soliciting more input as to the approach. Please go ahead and commit - I will open another PR for our approach.
